if it were i who currently gave a shit about the award, i would have at least tried to find the reason behind why it was removed from me and attempt to appeal it, but since i could care less, i didnt

now what was you were reasoning behind bringing this up randomly in a thread that has nothing to do with the matter

item.title: Pointer/Reference variables?
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

[code]public class Poop
{
private T poop = null;

public Poop(T o)
{
	poop = o;
}

public void set(T o)
{
	poop = o;
}

public T get()
{
	return poop;
}

}[/code]

[code]Poop mine = new Poop(1);
Poop yours = mine;

mine.set(15);

System.out.println(yours.get()); //prints 15

yours.set(3);

System.out.println(mine.get()); //prints 3[/code]

did this without compiling, a little rusty with generics so i dont now if it works >.>

Read full topic

item.description:

you can use the wrapper classes
[/quote]

O MAI GOD NO MORE C GURU!!!

@op
there is no logical point to this. You are asking how you make int two equal one and have one change whenever and whatever to does. This would create a infinite loop and one could not be different from the other.[/quote]Are you a fucking idiot? Of course theres a point to it. What happens if you want to pass an object of say an IO stream to another class, maybe a data handling class, you don’t create a whole new stream do you… you use your object pointer.

item.title: Pointer/Reference variables?
item.dc:creator: @unlimitedorb unlimitedorb
item.description:
@unlimitedorb wrote:

[quote=“BAsh, post:13, topic:307311”][quote author=oksuper_ link=topic=403461.msg2987841#msg2987841 date=1255124791]

you can use the wrapper classes

Could you explain? Thanks.
[/quote]in java, every data type has its respective ‘wrapper object’ which can be treated either as an object, or the data type itself

for example: int = Integer, byte = Byte, char = Character, etc

wtf really i did not know that:

class SomeUserDefinedDataType { } so whats the the wrapper for that?

Object[/quote]
If you’re going to stretch the meaning of the term “wrapper”, then a user defined data type is a wrapper for Object (not the other way around).

Read full topic

for example: int = Integer, byte = Byte, char = Character, etc[/quote]

ps the java primitive wrapper classes are immutable, so that wouldn’t quite be what he wanted.

item.title: Pointer/Reference variables?
item.dc:creator: @ownagesbot ownagesbot
item.description:
@ownagesbot wrote:

The point is that he thinks his Integer object is pointing to his primitive x. He must understand that the variable xx is an object pointer to an object of type Integer. In Java you can’t just point to anything, only objects. Hence why you can’t point to a primitive. This is what the wrappers are used for.

Read full topic

item.title: Pointer/Reference variables?
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

[quote=“The Beatz, post:6, topic:307311”][code]
public class Pointers
{
public static void main(String[] args)
{
System.out.println(xx);
x = 10;
System.out.println(xx);
}

public static int x = 5;
static Integer xx = new Integer(x);

}
[/code]

Is that what you mean? Tried this some time ago and didn’t work in the way I wanted. Both println’s printed 5.[/quote]

Of course both println’s printed 5, xx is created with the value of 5, it doesn’t auto-update when you change the variable it was started with. If you had done xx = 10, then it would have printed 10 the second time.

Read full topic

item.description:
@The_Beatz wrote:

public class Pointers
{
    public static void main(String[] args)
    {
        System.out.println(xx);
        x = 10;
        System.out.println(xx);
    }

    public static int x = 5;
    static Integer xx = new Integer(x);
}

Is that what you mean? Tried this some time ago and didn’t work in the way I wanted. Both println’s printed 5.

item.title: Pointer/Reference variables?
item.dc:creator: @The_Beatz The Beatz
item.description:
@The_Beatz wrote:

I can do this:

public class Class1
{
}

Class1 cl1 = new Class1();

I would also like to do that with variables.
So if I have:
int one = 5; and int two;
then I would like to point int two at int one so that whenever I do int intName = two; it will get the value from int one even if the value of int one changes constantly. I would also like to edit the value of int one by pointing at it through int two(two = 55; int intName = one - intName would be 55 here).

Read full topic
